title: Make it Scream, Make it Burn by Leslie Jamison, review: railing, roaring essays on humanity
text:
Homo sum: humani nil a me alienum puto,” reads the tattoo on Leslie Jamison’s arm: “I am human: nothing human is alien to me.” The epigraph for her first essay collection, The Empathy Exams – deliberations on the pain of others – which was published to rapturous praise in 2014, it reappears here in her second collection, Make it Scream, Make it Burn, more as a reprimand.

“I’d gotten it with heartfelt intentions […] an expression of kinship and curiosity,” she explains in a piece about visiting Sri Lanka while on an assignment for a travel magazine, a country where the skeletons of genocide victims are buried in the sand of its so-called “unspoilt” beaches, “but now my own arm admonished me.
